Abstract: The pipeline system is an important part of the Natural Gas production chain. In Brazil, the gas distribution pipelines comprise a network over 38.000 kilometers long, which has been growing every year. Compared to other modes of transport, such as road transport, the use of pipeline for gas transportation presents several advantages in the connection of production, processing and distribution units, such as: greater reliability, safety, efficiency and lower cost. Despite these benefits, however, pipelines also bring the threat to leak. The main objective of the present work is to develop a low-cost diagnostic system, based on pressure variation analysis for leak detection, sizing and location in gas distribution pipelines operating at low and middle pressures. The Pressure Point Analysis (PPA) method and methods based on Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), were used and experimental tests were carried out using a prototype that was built to a gas distribution pipeline section. The pressure variation and temperature data were used to train ANNs models for leak detection, sizing and location. The system was able to detect close to 100% of the leak cases. In the ANN test for the leak size, a R-squared value, equal to 0,99 was obtained. The average cost for developing the system was USD 15. The results have proven to be promising, and the potential of using this technique in a low-cost portable system for detecting, locating and predicting leak sizes in gas distribution pipelines.
Keywords: Natural gas distribution pipelines; leak detection; Pressure Point Analysis (PPA), Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs)
1. Introduction

The growing consumption of products from the petrochemical industry and the high energy demand have increased the need to transport oil, oil products and natural gas. Pipelines provide natural gas to many homes, offices, commercial buildings, electric utilities, hospitals, and so forth. (TERZIAN, 2005) Pipelines have been mainly classified into three groups: transfer or gathering,

transport and distribution. (ANP, 2010) Pipelines in the natural gas supply chain are an important element to connects the production, processing and distribution units. (WEGELIN, 2014) (HENRIE et The transfer pipelines or gathering lines flow the natural gas from the Exploration and Production (E&P) sites, such as offshore drilling, well completion, producing wells, storage facilities and LNG terminals to Natural Gas Processing Units (NGPU), connecting upstream and midstream sectors of the oil and gas industry. The transport pipelines or transmission lines connect the processing systems through the distribution networks, also flow de natural gas to the large volume consumers, such as large industries and electric power generations. Lastly, in downstream, there are two types of distribution pipelines, mains and services lines. (MELAINA et al, 2013) They are responsible for delivering gas to natural gas companies and the end users (households and commercial/industrial facilities). (SOUSA, 2007) In Brazil, the distribution pipelines network corresponds to more than 38.600 kilometres, which has been growing considerably every year. (ANP, 2019) (MME apud BNDES, 2020) The utilization rates have been increased, especially, by household and electric power generation sectors. According to the Brazilian Association of Pipeline Gas Distribution Companies (ABEGAS), these sectors were the only ones that showed positive growth in consumption between 2019 and 2020. For this reason, the trend is that increase, either, the capacity of natural gas distribution pipelines. (MME, 2021) Pipeline transport has advantages such as greater reliability and safety when compared to other transport methods, such as road transport. In addition, the use of canalized natural gas in households, commercial centers and industries is safer than the use of cylinder stored gas, avoiding the threat of explosion and it does not require exchange, transport and storage space. Moreover, natural gas is lighter than air and dissipates quickly in the event of a leak and it is convenient for continuous gas supply. (SANTOS, 2015) Despite these benefits, however, pipelines also bring a common threat: the potential to leak. The pipelines are susceptible to corrosion, installation failures, manufacturing defects, inadequate maintenance, sudden pressure variations and intervention by third parties. Therefore, structural failures can occur in the pipeline network resulting in leakage. These leaks can damage the environment and the population. For companies, they can lead to unscheduled interruption of production/operation, in addition to high economic losses due to loss of products, fines imposed by environmental protection agencies and material damage to the company's facilities or to the third party‚Äôs patrimonies. (TERZIAN, Therefore, efficient methods for detecting and locating leaks are essential in the operation of pipelines. Commonly, leak detection methods are based on process variables such as flow

(BILLMANN, 1984), temperature (YANG et al., 2019) (UKIL et al., 2016) and pressure (SILVA et al., 1996) (JIN et al., 1998) (SCHLATTMAN, 1991). In the case of a gas distribution system, pressure is one of the main variables in monitoring the operation. Through pressure measurements, it is possible to control the system in order to obtain the highest flow rate at the lowest possible cost without exceeding the pressure limits specified in the process control. Thus, pressure plays an important role in adjusting operating variables, setting alarms and detecting leaks. These factors are essential for the safety and operation of pipelines. (KENNEDY, 1993) Leak detection systems include direct observation approaches of various kinds and technology-based systems that are generally classified as either internal (software based) or external (hardware based), as proposed by Lu et al (2020), Adegboye et al (2019) and Henrie et al (2016). The internal leak detection system utilizes pipeline physical measurements to infer if a leak has occurred. The physical measurements may include flow rates, pressures, and temperatures. Some examples of these external systems include negative pressure wave (WANG et al, 2015), pressure point analysis (SCOTT & BARRUFET, 2003 apud MURVAV e SILEA, 2012), dynamic modelling (ZHANG et al, 2014), digital signal processing (WAN et al, 2012), mass-volume balance (KARIM et al, 2015) and artificial neural network as a fault detection and diagnosis tool (BELSITO et al, 1998) (CAPUTO e PELAGAGGE, 2003) (SANTOS, 2011).

The external leak detection systems differ from internal leak detection systems because they use a variety of means to detect a leakage or a change in the pipe surrounding environment that do not rely on measured pipeline parameters. Several leak detection methods hardware based have been proposed in the last years using different working principles and technics, such as fibre optic sensor (NIKLES et al, 2009), acoustic method (SANTOS, 2015) (MENG, 2012), vibroacoustic (GARCIA, 2010), ground penetration radar (GPR) (HOARAU et al, 2017), SmartBall (ARIARATNAM & CHANDRASEKARAN, 2010), vapour sampling (BRYCE et al, 2002) and infrared thermography (MANEKIYA et al, 2016).

Although a variety of leak detection methods have been developed, in practice, many concessionaires responsible for operating natural gas distribution networks apply inefficient leak detection methods, known as: manual, non-technical (MUVAY & SILEA, 2012), direct (FOLGA, 2007) or biological (ZHANG, 1997). These methods are based on periodic inspections, visual observation and patrolling along the pipeline range. Furthermore, natural gas is odorized (that is, it is mixed with substances that attribute a smell to the gas) in order to easily and quickly detect leaks. These methods restrict leak detection to the use of human senses. Because of this, the use of portable equipment has been widely requested for this type of operation. Nevertheless, portable equipments are based on sensors capable of detecting and measuring the concentration of gases in the environment. (MARQUES,

2017) These external techniques which involve detection done from outside the pipeline may be unable to detect very small leaks and the leak location time is very long and laborious. (MARQUES, 2017) (MUVAY & SILEA, 2012) In this context, the objective of this work was to develop and test a portable and low-cost system capable of detecting, sizing and locating leaks in internal gas distribution networks at low and middle pressure based on methods for the analysis of pressure variation. Based on literature reviews about the state-of-the-art on leak detection and localization techniques (LU et al, 2020) (ADEGBOYE et al, 2019) (BAROUDI et al, 2019) (HENRIE et al, 2016) (MURVAV & SILEA, 2012) the Pressure Point Analysis (PPA) method and methods based on Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) were selected for leak detection, sizing and location based on pressure analysis.

If the pressure variation of the new input data is considerably smaller than the previous average value or a predefined threshold, this may indicate a leakage event. (ADEGBOYE et al., 2019) Statistical methods can also be applied to confirm whether this pressure variation is due to leakage or not. The Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) have been the focus of attention, mostly due to their wide applicability. As described by De Souza Jr. (2005), in the field of Process Engineering, ANNs can be applied in sensor measurement processing and data analysis - correlating them and obtaining patterns; fault detection and diagnosis (FDD); and process control, such as predictive control based on neural networks.

The incentive to apply ANN-based methods in the present work was based on previous works that used ANNs as a data analysis tool applied to leakage detection, sizing and localization, which showed promising results.

Belsito and contributors (1998) who based their work on measurements of the inlet and outlet flow rates of the pipeline and also on pressure data collected at 13 points along the pipeline. In this work, the pipeline transported liquefied ammonia. Two neural networks were implemented: the first for leak detection and magnitude, and the second for leak localization ‚Äì which was activated if the leak alarm was triggered. The dataset was composed of cases with and without leakage pre-processed based on moving average. In the implementation of the second leakage location network the pipeline

was divided into 12 sections according to the data obtained from 13 collection stations. The results showed that the system is effective for leak detection and magnitude, even for leak cases smaller than 1% of the flow rate. The results for leaks localization demonstrated greater accuracy for leaks of larger proportions (5 and 10% of flow), since for leaks of 1% the flow rate, the correct locations predicted by the ANN was around 50%.

Santos (2011) studied based on the acoustic method and the analysis of pressure transients the use of neural networks to detect leaks and estimate the magnitude and location of leaks. Microphones were used to capture the sound signals of the leaks for two types of pipes carrying compressed air: a flexible and a rigid galvanized iron pipe. In addition, different initial compressed air pressure conditions of 2, 4 and 6 kgf/cm2 were used. The diameters of the leak holes varied from 1 to 3 mm. The experimental data obtained from the microphone was pre-processed and used as input to the first neural model to leak detect and estimate the magnitude of the simulated leak. When the leak is detected by the first model, a second neural model is run to estimate the location of the leak. The results show that for all cases for rigid piping and for cases at pressures of 4 and 6 kgf/cm2 for flexible piping, the neural models presented 100% accuracy in detecting leaks. The neural model to determine the location of the leak showed a good performance in predicting the location with a maximum error of 0.6 m for the rigid pipe, with compressed air at 6 kgf/cm The type of ANNs implemented in these previous works were multi-layer perceptron (MLP). The MLP network is a feedforward multi-layer network, and its training is supervised, using the backpropagation algorithm as the training method. (BRAGA, 2007) (HAYKIN, 2001) However, RBF or radial basis functions networks have been also employed in applications for pipeline leak detection. Junru and collaborators (2013) developed a hybrid leak detection method for large gas pipelines based on RBF neural networks and model building from transport phenomena equations.
Based on this context, MLP and RBF ANNs will be trained for leak detection (classification model) and estimation of leak size and location (regression model).

4. Conclusions
The experimental apparatus developed in this work demonstrate to be a representation of a real system of middle and low pressure gas distribution pipelines. Therefore, it can be used in

residential, commercial and industrial applications, mainly small ones. It can be easily portable adapted for measurements directly in the field, which allows it to be connected to pipelines from adapters making the operation and inspections in valves, connections and piping, especially in underground galleries, easily.

Leakage experimental tests presented in this work showed that pressure variables measured at the end of the pipeline undergoes significant and instantaneous variations for all leak hole diameters and locations occurring along the pipeline section. Different leak diameter tests indicate a direct relationship between the pressure variation measured and the hole size. The Point Pressure Analysis (PPA) method proved to be a low-cost and easy-to-use method for analyzing pressure variation. Thus, it can be easily implemented in natural gas distribution networks.

Leak detection based on ANNs showed results of almost 100% correct predictions. For the leak size detection, the network presented an RMSE average values around 0,30 for training, validation and testing. However, for the leak location detection cases, the networks results are not significant. The results have proven to be promising as a low-cost alternative and easy to apply portable system for detecting leakage events and predicting leak sizes in natural gas distribution pipelines.
